questions.text: A 52-year-old female patient is undergoing chemotherapy for breast cancer. The oncology team is concerned about the risk of febrile neutropenia due to the chemotherapeutic regimen. They are contemplating the use of a granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) and discuss the option of using pegylated-filgrastim or filgrastim. Which of the following is true about pegylated-filgrastim as compared to filgrastim?

options.label: A
options.text: Duration of action is longer than filgrastim

options.label: B
options.text: Added advantage is that it can be taken orally

options.label: C
options.text: Pegylated filgrastim is GM-CSF whereas filgrastim is G-CSF.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not effective in the treatment of severe neutropenia.

questions.correct_answer: A. Duration of action is longer than filgrastim
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Duration of action is longer than filgrastim.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient is being treated for chronic neuropathic pain with an oral medication. The healthcare team monitors the drug's plasma concentration over time. Which parameter on the plasma concentration vs. time graph helps to guide dose adjustments to maximize efficacy without causing toxicity?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cmax

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Important points about the PC-T graph:
  • ➤ Cmax helps assess peak drug levels for efficacy and toxicity. Tmax indicates the rate of absorption. AUC tells about extent of drug absorption. T1/2 helps determine dosing intervals.
  • ➤ Cmax helps assess peak drug levels for efficacy and toxicity.
  • ➤ Cmax
  • ➤ Tmax indicates the rate of absorption.
  • ➤ Tmax
  • ➤ AUC tells about extent of drug absorption.
  • ➤ AUC
  • ➤ T1/2 helps determine dosing intervals.
  • ➤ T1/2

questions.text: Acetylcholine acts through M3 receptor stimulation to cause increase in GI motility whereas adrenaline acts via beta 2 receptors to cause decrease in GI motility. Which type of antagonism it is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Physiological Antagonism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Physiological antagonism occurs when two drugs act on different receptors or pathways to produce opposite physiological effects, without interacting directly. This is in contrast to pharmacological antagonism , where two drugs compete for the same receptor, and chemical antagonism , where two substances chemically neutralize each other. Understanding the type of antagonism is critical in predicting and managing drug interactions in clinical practice.
  • ➤ Physiological antagonism
  • ➤ pharmacological antagonism
  • ➤ chemical antagonism

questions.text: Identify the type of inhibition given in the graph?
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Mixed

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a correct match of the adverse effect and mechanism of action of imipramine?

options.label: B
options.text: Dry mouth – M3 Muscarinic receptor blockade

questions.explanation: Ans. D) Hypotension – D2 receptor blockade

questions.text: In a dog blood pressure experiment, a researcher injected phentolamine first followed by epinephrine and the recordings of the effect are shown in the diagram given below. This phenomenon is known as?
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Vasomotor reversal of Dale

questions.text: A 55-year-old man who received a kidney transplant three months ago is admitted to the hospital with high-grade fever, malaise, and abdominal discomfort. On examination, he exhibits right upper quadrant tenderness. Lab investigations reveal abnormal liver enzymes, and a blood culture returns positive for cytomegalovirus (CMV). His current immunosuppressive regimen includes tacrolimus. What is the primary pharmacological action of tacrolimus that might have predisposed this patient to develop a CMV infection?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Inhibition of calcineurin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation of all the options:
  • • A) Inhibition of calcineurin: Tacrolimus acts by inhibiting calcineurin, which plays a pivotal role in T-cell activation. This immunosuppressive action can make the patient susceptible to infections such as CMV.
  • • B) Blockade of IL-2 receptor: This is a mechanism of other immunosuppressive drugs like basiliximab but not tacrolimus. Therefore, it is not relevant to the patient's current condition.
  • • C) IMP dehydrogenase inhibition: This is the mechanism of mycophenolate mofetil, another immunosuppressive drug. It is not applicable to tacrolimus.
  • • D) Dihydro-orotate dehydrogenase inhibition: This mechanism is associated with drugs like leflunomide but is not relevant to the action of tacrolimus.
  • • Thus, the primary pharmacological action of tacrolimus that might have predisposed this patient to develop a CMV infection is the inhibition of calcineurin.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female with a history of glaucoma presents to the ophthalmologist with complaints of blurred vision and eye irritation. The patient reports that she has been using an anti-glaucoma medication for the past six months, and her symptoms began to appear gradually over the past few weeks. Appearance of eye is as shown in the figure. Which of the following anti-glaucoma drugs is likely to produce this adverse effect?
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Latanoprost.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient with a history of heart failure and atrial fibrillation has been taking digoxin for several months. He recently started on a new medication. He presents to the clinic with symptoms of nausea, vomiting, and visual disturbances. On testing, plasma levels of digoxin were elevated. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Quinidine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Drugs like quinidine that inhibit P-glycoprotein can significantly increase the plasma levels of digoxin , leading to toxicity. Classic symptoms of digoxin toxicity include nausea, vomiting, confusion, and visual disturbances (e.g., yellow or blurred vision). Clinicians must be aware of potential drug interactions, particularly with medications affecting renal or hepatic excretion pathways like P-glycoprotein inhibitors. Regular monitoring of digoxin levels is essential when such drugs are co-administered.
  • ➤ quinidine
  • ➤ P-glycoprotein
  • ➤ digoxin

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with symptoms of urinary urgency, frequency, and nocturia. He has been diagnosed with overactive bladder. On further questioning, the patients tells that he forgets the things easily and is on rivastigmine therapy for the same. Which of the following drugs is a beta-3 adrenergic receptor agonist that is effective in treating this patient's symptoms without interfering with treatment of his dementia?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For patients with overactive bladder who are also being treated for dementia , it is important to avoid antimuscarinic agents like tolterodine due to their cognitive side effects. Beta-3 adrenergic receptor agonists like vibegron are effective alternatives that increase bladder capacity without interfering with cholinergic medications like rivastigmine, thus preserving cognitive function.
  • ➤ overactive bladder
  • ➤ dementia
  • ➤ tolterodine
  • ➤ Beta-3 adrenergic receptor agonists
  • ➤ vibegron

questions.text: The following table gives the data of AUC of drug A alone and AUC of drug A when combined with drug B. p value is <0.01. Which of the following statement regarding these drugs is most correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Drug B decreases the first pass metabolism of drug A

options.label: B
options.text: Drug B decreases the systemic metabolism of drug A

options.label: C
options.text: Drug B decreases the intestinal absorption of drug A

options.label: D
options.text: Drug B decreases the renal clearance of drug A

questions.correct_answer: C. Drug B decreases the intestinal absorption of drug A
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Drug B decreases the intestinal absorption of drug A

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The AUC represents the total drug exposure over time and is influenced by absorption, distribution, metabolism, and elimination. A significant reduction in AUC, as observed when drug A is combined with drug B, suggests that drug B is likely interfering with the absorption of drug A. When evaluating drug interactions, it’s important to consider the mechanism of action (e.g., effects on absorption, metabolism, or excretion) to optimize therapeutic regimens and avoid suboptimal drug levels or adverse effects.
  • ➤ AUC
  • ➤ absorption

questions.text: A 43-year-old, insulin-dependent diabetic patient is diagnosed with migraine and begins therapy with a drug to prevent further attacks of migraine. Three days later, he measures his blood glucose at home and finds that it is 53 mg/dL. He recalibrates his glucose testing apparatus and repeats the test, only to find that the first reading was accurate. He is concerned that his hypoglycemia did not produce the normal premonitory signs and symptoms. Which of the following medications was most likely prescribed to him?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Propranolol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Propranolol , a non-selective beta-blocker, is often used for migraine prophylaxis but can mask the signs of hypoglycemia in diabetic patients by blunting the sympathetic nervous system's response. This makes it challenging for patients to detect low blood sugar, as the typical warning signs are reduced. In managing diabetic patients who require beta-blocker therapy, close monitoring of blood glucose levels is essential to avoid hypoglycemia unawareness.
  • ➤ Propranolol
  • ➤ hypoglycemia

questions.text: A drug effect that is produced by therapeutic doses of both timolol and amiodarone is blockade of:
questions.explanation: Ans. C. Beta-adrenoceptors.

questions.text: Metformin is least likely to reduce blood sugar in which of the following patients?
questions.explanation: Ans. B. Non-diabetics

questions.text: A 67-year-old postmenopausal woman with a history of osteoporosis is being evaluated for potential pharmacological treatments to strengthen her bones. She has tried lifestyle modifications, including weight-bearing exercises and calcium supplements, with limited improvement. Her physician is considering various pharmacological agents to inhibit osteoclastic activity and thereby prevent further bone loss. Which of the following medications does NOT primarily act by inhibiting osteoclasts?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Teriparatide

Explanation:

  • • Explanation of Options:
  • • a) Denosumab: This is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits the RANKL (Receptor Activator for Nuclear Factor κ B Ligand), which is essential for the formation and function of osteoclasts. Thus, it inhibits osteoclast activity.
  • • b) Strontium ranelate: This drug is used in the treatment of osteoporosis and works by both promoting bone formation and inhibiting bone resorption. It is thought to inhibit osteoclasts, although the exact mechanism is not well understood.
  • • c) Teriparatide: This is the correct answer. Teriparatide is a recombinant form of parathyroid hormone. It is actually an anabolic (bone-building) agent that stimulates osteoblast activity, rather than inhibiting osteoclasts.
  • • d) Raloxifene: This is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that inhibits bone resorption by osteoclasts, thus serving to preserve bone mass in conditions like osteoporosis.
  • • Teriparatide does not inhibit osteoclasts but stimulates osteoblasts, making it the correct answer for the drug that does not act by inhibiting osteoclasts.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman goes to her dermatologist to have a mole removed. The patient tells her physician that she had an allergic reaction to a local anesthetic the last time she had dental work performed. Examination of her dental records by her dentist reveals that the patient received tetracaine for a tooth extraction. Which of the following drugs would be appropriate for the present procedure?
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Prilocaine

questions.text: Following the treatment of an oral abscess with clindamycin, a patient develops a greenish, foul-smelling watery diarrhea with left lower quadrant pain. Other signs and symptoms include fever, leukocytosis, and lethargy. If the toxin produced by Clostridium difficile is detected in the stool, the patient would most appropriately be treated with:
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Fidaxomicin.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the clinic with a palpable lump in her left breast that she noticed while showering. She reports no associated pain, discharge, or skin changes. Her past medical history is unremarkable, and she has no known family history of breast or ovarian cancer. Her last mammogram was two years ago and showed no abnormalities. After appropriate investigations including mammogram, ultrasound, and biopsy, she is diagnosed with stage II breast cancer. The biopsy reveals that the cancer is HER2-positive, but estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) negative. Which of the following oral drugs is likely to be effective in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Lapatinib

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In HER2-positive breast cancer, treatments that specifically target the HER2 receptor, such as lapatinib (an oral tyrosine kinase inhibitor), are effective. These cancers do not respond to hormonal therapies like tamoxifen or letrozole , which target estrogen receptor-positive breast cancers. Understanding the molecular profile of the cancer is essential in choosing the most effective treatment, as therapies are tailored to the specific receptors expressed by the tumor cells.
  • ➤ lapatinib
  • ➤ tamoxifen
  • ➤ letrozole

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to the clinic with recurrent episodes of renal colic. Laboratory tests and imaging confirm the presence of high-calcium renal stones. He has no other significant past medical history. What is the most useful diuretic in the treatment of his recurrent calcium stones?
questions.explanation: Ans. C. Hydrochlorothiazide.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is scheduled for emergency surgery due to acute appendicitis. He has no significant past medical history, but his medical team is concerned about the use of succinylcholine as a neuromuscular blocking agent for intubation. Which of the following statements about succinylcholine is true?

options.label: B
options.text: It has a long duration of action.

options.label: C
options.text: It is the drug of choice in non-traumatic rhabdomyolysis.

options.label: D
options.text: It is useful in patients with spinal cord injuries with paraplegia.

questions.correct_answer: A. It may induce life-threatening hyperkalemia.
questions.explanation: Ans. A. It may induce life-threatening hyperkalemia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with acute liver and renal failure. Her lab reports show a serum bilirubin level of 8 mg/dl and a serum creatinine level of 4 mg/dl. She requires muscle relaxation for mechanical ventilation. What would be the muscle relaxant of choice in this patient?
questions.explanation: Ans. C. Atracurium.

questions.text: Which of the following combination of drug and its indication is FALSE?

options.label: C
options.text: Tafenoquine: Single dose treatment of P. falciparum malaria

options.label: D
options.text: Remdesivir: Moderate to severe COVID-19 pneumonia

questions.correct_answer: C. Tafenoquine: Single dose treatment of P. falciparum malaria
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Tafenoquine: Single dose treatment of P. falciparum malaria

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tafenoquine is used for the radical cure of P. vivax malaria and is not indicated for single-dose treatment of P. falciparum malaria . First-line treatment for P. falciparum malaria typically involves artemisinin-based combination therapies (ACTs) . Pretomanid is crucial in the treatment of MDR tuberculosis, and Enfuvirtide is used in HIV management. Remdesivir is an antiviral used in moderate to severe cases of COVID-19 pneumonia.
  • ➤ Tafenoquine is used for the radical cure of P. vivax malaria and is not indicated for single-dose treatment of P. falciparum malaria .
  • ➤ Tafenoquine
  • ➤ P. vivax malaria
  • ➤ P. falciparum malaria
  • ➤ First-line treatment for P. falciparum malaria typically involves artemisinin-based combination therapies (ACTs) .
  • ➤ P. falciparum malaria
  • ➤ artemisinin-based combination therapies (ACTs)
  • ➤ Pretomanid is crucial in the treatment of MDR tuberculosis, and Enfuvirtide is used in HIV management.
  • ➤ Pretomanid
  • ➤ Enfuvirtide
  • ➤ Remdesivir is an antiviral used in moderate to severe cases of COVID-19 pneumonia.
  • ➤ Remdesivir

questions.text: A 27-year-old male diagnosed with HIV seeks guidance from his primary care doctor for appropriate treatment. Given the significant drop in his CD4 counts, initiation of HAART (Highly Active Antiretroviral Therapy) is being contemplated. Concerning the role of ritonavir for this patient, which statement holds true?

options.label: A
options.text: Ritonavir is commonly used to inhibit the HIV protease enzyme along with other drugs in HAART regimen.

options.label: B
options.text: This agent is associated with resistance when used in combination with another protease inhibitor.

options.label: C
options.text: It is used primarily for its inhibitory effect on CYP3A4.

options.label: D
options.text: This is an excellent single agent for use in HAART therapy.

questions.correct_answer: C. It is used primarily for its inhibitory effect on CYP3A4.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. It is used primarily for its inhibitory effect on CYP3A4.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation of Other Options
  • • A. Ritonavir is commonly used to inhibit the HIV protease enzyme along with other drugs in HAART regimen.
  • • A. Ritonavir is commonly used to inhibit the HIV protease enzyme along with other drugs in HAART regimen.
  • • While ritonavir does have protease inhibitory activity, its primary role in HAART regimens is as a pharmacokinetic enhancer of other protease inhibitors rather than as the main protease inhibitor.
  • • B. This agent is associated with resistance when used in combination with another protease inhibitor.
  • • B. This agent is associated with resistance when used in combination with another protease inhibitor.
  • • Ritonavir, when used in low doses as a booster, does not contribute significantly to resistance. Its role is to increase the effectiveness of other protease inhibitors without leading to increased resistance.
  • • D. This is an excellent single agent for use in HAART therapy.
  • • D. This is an excellent single agent for use in HAART therapy.
  • • Ritonavir is not used as a single agent in HAART therapy due to its side effect profile and the development of resistance when used alone. It is always used in combination with other antiretroviral drugs.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Ritonavir is primarily used in HAART regimens for its strong inhibitory effect on the cytochrome P450 enzyme CYP3A4. This inhibition enhances the pharmacokinetics of other protease inhibitors, increasing their plasma levels and efficacy, which allows for lower dosages and reduced side effects.

questions.text: A 24-year-old Indian man, pursuing his post-graduation, recently returned from Africa where he completed an academic research project. A few weeks after his return, he visits the hospital after testing positive for Plasmodium vivax malaria. The doctor recommends primaquine for the radical cure of his P. vivax infection. Shortly after beginning the regimen, the patient exhibits yellowing of the eyes. What could be the most probable reason for this symptom?

options.label: A
options.text: Primaquine merely stains the tears yellow; this isn't genuine yellowing of the eyes.

questions.correct_answer: C. Deficiency of a specific enzyme.
questions.explanation: Ans. C. Deficiency of a specific enzyme.

questions.text: A 29-year-old sexually active, HIV-negative male visits his healthcare provider with a painless sore on his inner lip and a non-itchy rash on the soles of his feet. He recalls having a non-tender ulcer on his scrotum about a month and a half ago, which resolved on its own. He receives an intramuscular injection of benzathine penicillin G and is discharged. How might the treatment approach for this patient have been modified?

options.label: A
options.text: The choice of antibiotic was not appropriate, and another class should have been selected.

options.label: B
options.text: The correct treatment would involve a different form of penicillin G, rather than benzathine.

options.label: C
options.text: There is no need for changes; the treatment administered is correct.

options.label: D
options.text: After the initial injection, a follow-up dose should be given after 7 days.

questions.correct_answer: C. There is no need for changes; the treatment administered is correct.
questions.explanation: Ans. C. There is no need for changes; the treatment administered is correct.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the clinic with symptoms of fever, weight loss, and splenomegaly. She has recently returned from a trip to a region known for endemic visceral leishmaniasis, also known as Kala-azar. Which of the following medications is suitable for single-dose treatment of Kala-azar?
questions.explanation: Ans. B. Liposomal Amphotericin B

questions.text: 35-year-old patient presents to the clinic with a swollen, painful abscess on the forehead that is discharging pus. The clinical findings strongly suggest a pus-forming gram-positive bacterial infection. Which of the following antibiotics is LEAST likely to be effective for treating this infection?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Cotrimoxazole

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Amoxycillin: An aminopenicillin effective against many gram-positive bacteria, often utilized for skin infections. Cloxacillin: An isoxazolyl penicillin designed to counter gram-positive bacteria, especially strains of Staphylococcus aureus. Cotrimoxazole (Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole): Although it has broad-spectrum activity, Cotrimoxazole is not the preferred choice for purulent (pus-forming) gram-positive skin infections. Its efficacy can be reduced in the presence of pus, and it's not the primary choice for such infections. Cephalexin: A first-generation cephalosporin that effectively targets gram-positive cocci and is often employed for skin and soft tissue infections.
  • • Amoxycillin: An aminopenicillin effective against many gram-positive bacteria, often utilized for skin infections.
  • • Cloxacillin: An isoxazolyl penicillin designed to counter gram-positive bacteria, especially strains of Staphylococcus aureus.
  • • Cotrimoxazole (Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole): Although it has broad-spectrum activity, Cotrimoxazole is not the preferred choice for purulent (pus-forming) gram-positive skin infections. Its efficacy can be reduced in the presence of pus, and it's not the primary choice for such infections.
  • • Cephalexin: A first-generation cephalosporin that effectively targets gram-positive cocci and is often employed for skin and soft tissue infections.
  • • In the context of a purulent skin infection, Cotrimoxazole is less likely to be effective compared to the other options presented.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of diabetes presents to the hospital with a fever and worsening redness, swelling, and tenderness around his right leg. His blood cultures show methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). The patient is started on intravenous vancomycin for suspected MRSA cellulitis. Which of the following is a true statement regarding vancomycin?

options.label: B
options.text: It has the advantage of high oral bioavailability

options.label: C
options.text: It is highly effective against Pseudomonas

options.label: D
options.text: It is not susceptible to penicillinases

questions.correct_answer: D. It is not susceptible to penicillinases
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) It is not susceptible to penicillinases

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vancomycin is a bactericidal glycopeptide antibiotic that is primarily effective against Gram-positive organisms, including MRSA. It has poor oral bioavailability and is not effective against Gram-negative bacteria like Pseudomonas . Importantly, vancomycin is not susceptible to penicillinases because it does not work by targeting penicillin-binding proteins. This makes it effective against bacteria that produce β-lactamases, such as MRSA.
  • ➤ bactericidal
  • ➤ Gram-positive
  • ➤ poor oral bioavailability
  • ➤ not susceptible to penicillinases

questions.text: Chemical structure of a drug is shown in the figure below. It is drug of choice for:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Q fever

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Doxycycline , a tetracycline antibiotic with a four-ring chemical structure, is the drug of choice for infections caused by intracellular organisms, such as Q fever (caused by Coxiella burnetii ). It is not the drug of choice for enteric fever, MRSA pneumonia, or P. vivax malaria.
  • ➤ Doxycycline , a tetracycline antibiotic with a four-ring chemical structure, is the drug of choice for infections caused by intracellular organisms, such as Q fever (caused by Coxiella burnetii ). It is not the drug of choice for enteric fever, MRSA pneumonia, or P. vivax malaria.
  • ➤ Doxycycline
  • ➤ Q fever

questions.text: A 56-year-old male presents to the hospital with symptoms of fever, productive cough, and shortness of breath. His medical history includes recent surgery and prolonged hospitalization. A sputum culture reveals infection with Pseudomonas aeruginosa , and the infectious disease team decides to start treatment with a third-generation cephalosporin that has activity against Gram-negative bacteria, including Pseudomonas . Which of the following is a third-generation cephalosporin ?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ceftazidime

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Third-generation cephalosporins, like ceftazidime , are widely used for their broad spectrum of activity against Gram-negative organisms, including Pseudomonas aeruginosa . They are more resistant to β-lactamases than earlier generations, making them useful in treating hospital-acquired infections
  • ➤ ceftazidime

questions.text: Which of the following drugs binds irreversibly to the site labelled as B in the given figure?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Prasugrel

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prasugrel is an irreversible P2Y12 receptor inhibitor used to reduce the risk of thrombotic events in patients with acute coronary syndrome. It permanently blocks ADP-mediated platelet activation. In contrast, other agents like Cangrelor provide reversible P2Y12 inhibition, and Abciximab and Vorapaxar target different mechanisms of platelet inhibition.
  • ➤ Prasugrel
  • ➤ Cangrelor
  • ➤ Abciximab
  • ➤ Vorapaxar

questions.text: Which of the following statements about warfarin group of oral anticoagulants is false ?

options.label: A
options.text: They interfere with an early step in the synthesis of clotting factors

options.label: B
options.text: Irrespective of the dose administered, their anticoagulant effect has a latency of onset of 4-5 days

options.label: C
options.text: Their dose is adjusted by repeated measurement of INR

options.label: D
options.text: They are contraindicated during first trimester of pregnancy

questions.correct_answer: A. They interfere with an early step in the synthesis of clotting factors
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. They interfere with an early step in the synthesis of clotting factors

Explanation:

  • • B. Irrespective of the dose administered, their anticoagulant effect has a latency of onset of 4-5 days
  • • B. Irrespective of the dose administered, their anticoagulant effect has a latency of onset of 4-5 days
  • • This statement is true. Warfarin has a delayed onset of action because it does not affect clotting factors that have already been synthesized and are present in the bloodstream. It takes several days for these existing clotting factors to degrade and for the anticoagulant effect to become apparent.
  • • C. Their dose is adjusted by repeated measurement of INR
  • • C. Their dose is adjusted by repeated measurement of INR
  • • This statement is true. The dose of warfarin is adjusted based on the International Normalized Ratio (INR) to ensure that the patient's blood is maintained within the therapeutic range, which minimizes the risk of bleeding and thromboembolism.
  • • D. They are contraindicated during first trimester of pregnancy
  • • D. They are contraindicated during first trimester of pregnancy
  • • This statement is true. Warfarin is contraindicated during pregnancy, especially in the first trimester, due to its teratogenic effects. It can cause fetal warfarin syndrome, characterized by nasal hypoplasia and stippled epiphyses, among other congenital abnormalities.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Warfarin is an oral anticoagulant that inhibits the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase, affecting the carboxylation and activation of certain clotting factors. It has a delayed onset of action, typically taking 4-5 days, and its dose is adjusted based on INR measurements. Warfarin is contraindicated during pregnancy due to its teratogenic potential, especially in the first trimester.

questions.text: A 67-year-old female with atrial fibrillation is prescribed dabigatran, an oral direct thrombin inhibitor, for stroke prevention. A few months later, she is admitted to the emergency department with a gastrointestinal bleed. Which of the following drugs can be used to reverse the anticoagulant effect of dabigatran in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Idarucizumab

questions.text: A 58-year-old male undergoing chemotherapy for lung cancer is being treated with cisplatin , a platinum-based chemotherapeutic agent. On the third day of his treatment cycle, he develops severe, intractable vomiting. Which of the following is the agent of choice for controlling this vomiting?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Fosaprepitant

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV) , particularly with drugs like cisplatin that are highly emetogenic:
  • ➤ chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV)
  • ➤ cisplatin
  • ➤ Fosaprepitant (an NK1 receptor antagonist) is most effective for preventing delayed-phase vomiting . Granisetron and other 5-HT3 antagonists are more effective for acute-phase vomiting . Metoclopramide and domperidone are generally used for motility-related nausea but are not the first choice for CINV.
  • ➤ Fosaprepitant (an NK1 receptor antagonist) is most effective for preventing delayed-phase vomiting .
  • ➤ Fosaprepitant
  • ➤ delayed-phase vomiting
  • ➤ Granisetron and other 5-HT3 antagonists are more effective for acute-phase vomiting .
  • ➤ Granisetron
  • ➤ 5-HT3 antagonists
  • ➤ acute-phase vomiting
  • ➤ Metoclopramide and domperidone are generally used for motility-related nausea but are not the first choice for CINV.
  • ➤ Metoclopramide
  • ➤ domperidone

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

Beta-blockers , like labetalol, can exacerbate bronchoconstriction and should be used cautiously in asthmatic patients.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male undergoing shoulder surgery receives a brachial plexus block with 0.5% lignocaine for anesthesia. Shortly after the procedure, the patient develops signs of severe hypotension and cardiovascular collapse. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 20% lipid emulsion therapy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST) , especially with agents like lignocaine and bupivacaine, 20% lipid emulsion therapy is the gold standard treatment to reverse the toxic effects on the cardiovascular and central nervous systems. Early recognition and prompt administration of lipid therapy can be life-saving in these scenarios.
  • ➤ local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST)
  • ➤ 20% lipid emulsion therapy

questions.text: A 40-year-old obese female with schizophrenia is being considered for antipsychotic treatment. Which of the following antipsychotic drugs is associated with the least metabolic adverse effects?
questions.explanation:

questions.text: A 35-year-old female with a previous history of GTCS presents with convulsions which are ongoing since 25 minutes. What should be the appropriate management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lorazepam followed by valproate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In status epilepticus , immediate control of seizures is critical. Lorazepam is the first-line agent for rapidly stopping seizures, and once the acute phase is managed, valproate can be used for long-term seizure prevention. Other agents like ethosuximide and carbamazepine are not suitable for this clinical scenario, as they either lack the rapid onset required or are not effective for generalized tonic-clonic seizures.

questions.text: What does it mean when a drug has an oral bioavailability of 20 percent?

options.label: B

options.label: C

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 30 percent of the drug reaches the systemic circulation in unchanged form

  • ➤ Oral bioavailability is the proportion of a drug that reaches the systemic circulation in an unchanged form after oral administration. questions.text: A 62-year-old post-menopausal woman is diagnosed with estrogen receptor-positive (ER+) breast cancer. She has no significant history of other health conditions. Which of the following is the preferred drug for the treatment of breast cancer in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Letrozole

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For post-menopausal women with hormone receptor-positive breast cancer , letrozole (an aromatase inhibitor) is the preferred treatment. It reduces estrogen levels by inhibiting the aromatase enzyme, which is the primary source of estrogen in post-menopausal women. This helps to slow the growth of estrogen-dependent breast cancer. Tamoxifen is more commonly used in pre-menopausal women, while HER2-targeted therapies like trastuzumab and lapatinib are reserved for HER2-positive breast cancer.
  • ➤ hormone receptor-positive breast cancer
  • ➤ letrozole
  • ➤ Tamoxifen
  • ➤ HER2-targeted therapies

  • ➤ When a patient already on 2NRTIs + 1NNRTI (EFV)–based regimen has to be given 2HRZE + 4HRE–based ATT for the newly detected TB, same ART regimen can be continued without any modification. When a patient already on 2NRTIs + DTG–based regimen has to be given Rifampicin-based ATT for the newly detected TB, same ART regimen can be continued. However, since co-administered rifampicin reduces bioavailability of DTG, which can be overcome by an additional tablet of DTG 50 mg (at an interval of 12 hours with the regular dose of DTG) till the completion of ATT. Once the ATT is completed, additional tablet of DTG 50 mg should be stopped 2 weeks after stoppage of Rifampicin-containing treatment regimen. questions.text: A 32-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after ingesting an overdose of a medication. In order to enhance drug clearance, you consider the modification of urinary pH as a therapeutic measure. Knowing that manipulating the urinary pH can increase the excretion of certain drugs by altering their ionization state, which of the following drugs would not have its excretion increased by alkalinization of the urine?

Ans. C) Morphine

Explanation:

  • • Aspirin

  • • Option B.
  • • Methotrexate
  • • acidic drug
  • • alkalinization of the urine will increase its ionization
  • • Option D. Phenobarbitone : This is an acidic drug , and like aspirin and methotrexate , it is more ionized in alkaline urine, leading to increased excretion.

  • • Phenobarbitone
  • • acidic drug
  • • aspirin and methotrexate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ In cases of drug overdose , urinary alkalinization is utilized to increase the excretion of acidic drugs by enhancing their ionization , which does not apply to basic drugs like morphine that are better excreted in acidic conditions. Remember, the drugs ending with ‘ine’ are basic.

questions.text: Which of the following acts on α1, α2 and β1 receptors but does not stimulate β2 receptors?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Noradrenaline

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Noradrenaline (norepinephrine) acts on α1, α2, and β1 adrenergic receptors. It is a naturally occurring catecholamine that functions as a neurotransmitter and hormone in the body . Noradrenaline's action on α1 and α2 receptors is responsible for its vasoconstrictive effects , while its action on β1 receptors affects cardiac output by increasing the heart rate and myocardial contractility. It does not stimulate β2 receptors , which are primarily involved in bronchodilation and vasodilation .

questions.text: A 45-year-old individual with no significant past medical history presents to the emergency department with fever, malaise, and a new heart murmur. Blood cultures are drawn, and the results reveal Streptococcus viridans, indicating a diagnosis of streptococcal endocarditis. The patient is started on penicillin therapy but develops hives, pruritus, and respiratory distress within minutes of the first dose, suggesting an immediate hypersensitivity reaction to penicillin. Which of the following is an alternative drug that can be used to manage streptococcal endocarditis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vancomycin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For the treatment of streptococcal endocarditis in patients with a history of severe penicillin allergy , such as anaphylaxis, vancomycin is the preferred alternative due to its efficacy against Gram-positive bacteria and lack of cross-reactivity with β-lactam antibiotics. Cephalosporins, carbapenems, and monobactams are not recommended due to the potential for allergic reactions and/or their ineffectiveness against Gram-positive organisms like Streptococcus viridans.
  • ➤ streptococcal endocarditis
  • ➤ penicillin allergy
  • ➤ vancomycin
  • ➤ Gram-positive bacteria

questions.text: All the following drugs are effective against MRSA EXCEPT.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cefoperazone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Most β-lactam antibiotics (except for a few, like ceftaroline ) are ineffective against MRSA . Vancomycin , rifampicin , and linezolid are effective treatments for MRSA, but cefoperazone , as a third-generation cephalosporin, does not cover MRSA due to the altered PBPs that confer resistance.
  • ➤ β-lactam antibiotics
  • ➤ ceftaroline
  • ➤ ineffective
  • ➤ MRSA
  • ➤ Vancomycin
  • ➤ rifampicin
  • ➤ linezolid
  • ➤ cefoperazone

questions.text: Drug of choice for treatment of hypothyroidism in first trimester of pregnancy is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) L-thyroxine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The drug of choice for treating hypothyroidism during pregnancy, including the first trimester, is L-thyroxine (levothyroxine) . It is essential for maintaining normal thyroid hormone levels to ensure proper fetal development. Other drugs like Propylthiouracil and Carbimazole are used to treat hyperthyroidism, not hypothyroidism, and radioactive iodine is contraindicated in pregnancy.
  • ➤ L-thyroxine (levothyroxine)

questions.text: A 35-year-old female with a history of epilepsy is being evaluated for her response to a new antiepileptic medication. The physician decides to review the dose-response characteristics of the drug to determine the optimal therapeutic dose. The drug's efficacy and safety were assessed using a quantal dose-response curve (DRC) during clinical trials. Which of the following statements best describes the quantal dose-response curve (DRC)?

options.label: A
options.text: A quantal DRC measures the intensity of a drug's effect in a single patient at different doses.

options.label: B
options.text: A quantal DRC plots the cumulative percentage of a population that exhibits a specified all-or-none effect (e.g., seizure prevention) at different doses.

options.label: C
options.text: A quantal DRC is used to determine the dose at which 50% of an individual patient's maximum response is achieved.

options.label: D
options.text: A quantal DRC assesses the relationship between drug concentration and response in a continuous manner for each individual.

questions.correct_answer: B. A quantal DRC plots the cumulative percentage of a population that exhibits a specified all-or-none effect (e.g., seizure prevention) at different doses.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) A quantal DRC plots the cumulative percentage of a population that exhibits a specified all-or-none effect (e.g., seizure prevention) at different doses.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand that a quantal dose-response curve (DRC) represents the cumulative percentage of a population exhibiting a specified all-or-none effect at varying doses. It is used to determine important pharmacological parameters like the median effective dose (ED50), which is the dose at which 50% of the population achieves the desired therapeutic effect.

questions.text: A 54-year-old male with a history of chronic kidney disease (CKD) stage 4 presents with symptoms of fatigue, pallor, and shortness of breath. Laboratory investigations reveal hemoglobin levels of 8.5 g/dL (normal range: 13.8 to 17.2 g/dL in males), indicating anemia of CKD. Which of the following oral drugs can be used to treat anemia in this patient with CKD?
questions.explanation:
Ans.  A) Daprodustat

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Daprodustat is a novel oral hypoxia-inducible factor prolyl hydroxylase inhibitor (HIF-PHI) used to treat anemia in CKD patients. It offers an alternative to injectable erythropoiesis-stimulating agents by promoting endogenous erythropoietin production through the HIF pathway.

questions.text: All of the following are HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors except:

questions.text: Which of the following regarding Angiotensin II Receptor Blockers (ARBs) is not correctly matched?

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Valsartan: Given in combination with sacubitril as ARNI

questions.correct_answer: C. Olmesartan: Causes hypokalaemia in patients with CKD

  • ➤ Understand that ARBs generally cause hyperkalemia in patients with chronic kidney disease due to aldosterone inhibition, and Olmesartan is no exception. This contrasts with the false statement regarding hypokalemia . Additionally, recognize the unique benefits of Telmisartan in insulin resistance and Valsartan in combination therapy with sacubitril.

questions.text: All adverse effects of theophylline are mediated by adenosine A1 receptor antagonism except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) GI discomfort

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Most of the adverse effects of theophylline , including cardiac arrhythmias , diuresis , and seizures , are mediated by its antagonism of adenosine A1 receptors . However, GI discomfort is not related to adenosine receptor antagonism but is due to direct effects on gastric secretion and mucosal irritation.

questions.text: Adverse effect of orlistat is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Steatorrhea

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Orlistat is a useful medication for those looking to lose weight, especially in cases where diet and exercise alone have not been sufficient. Patients prescribed Orlistat should be counseled about the possibility of experiencing gastrointestinal side effects such as steatorrhea and advised on dietary adjustments to manage or minimize such effects, emphasizing a reduced fat intake.
